title: Manu Maʻu
text:
Manu Maʻu (born 24 August 1988) is a <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays as a forward for <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="Betfred%20Super%20League">Betfred Super League</a>. He has played for both <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> and <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> at international level. 
He previously played for the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>.
Background.
Ma'u was born in <a href="Auckland%2C%20New%20Zealand">Auckland, New Zealand</a>, and is of <a href="Tonga">Tonga</a>n descent. He attended <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> nursery <a href="St%20Paul%27s%20College%2C%20Auckland">St Paul's College, Auckland</a>.
He played his junior football for the <a href="Richmond%20Rovers">Richmond Rovers</a> and <a href="Marist%20Saints">Marist Saints</a>.
Early years.
Ma'u was an original member of Auckland's Roskill South-based "JDK", one of the many street <a href="gangs%20in%20New%20Zealand">gangs in New Zealand</a>. In 2007, after one of the gang was stabbed during an altercation, the gang gatecrashed a 21st birthday party in an alcohol-fuelled quest for vengeance, found the alleged perpetrators and "unleashed hell". Two months later, Maʻu was arrested along with his brother, Semisi, and later sentenced to three years in prison for his part in the brawl.
Ma'u was released in 2009 to work and continue his rugby league career, and joined the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors'</a> reserves team the <a href="Auckland%20Vulcans">Auckland Vulcans</a> in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Cup">New South Wales Cup</a>. But he found himself unable to play away games, as the Australian immigration department denied him a visa, citing his criminal history. In 2013, after his manager and the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> battled for a year to gain the necessary visa, Ma'u moved to Australia to play in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Cup">New South Wales Cup</a> for the <a href="Wentworthville%20Magpies">Wentworthville Magpies</a>, the Eels' reserves team.
A reformed man with a young family of his own, Ma'u was eager to put his past behind him and make the most of his opportunity with the Eels. Ma'u said "I want to repay Parramatta for their faith," "I want to build a future. I want my partner Alisi and my kids [Melino and Levi] to be proud of me and I want my family to realise I'm not that naughty boy that caused them pain."
Playing career.
2014.
In February 2014, Ma'u was included in the Eels inaugural <a href="2014%20Auckland%20Nines">2014 Auckland Nines</a> squad. In Round 1 of the <a href="2014%20NRL%20season">2014 NRL season</a>, Ma'u made his NRL debut for the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> at . Ma’u won the Man of the Match award on debut in the Eels 36-16 win at <a href="Parramatta%20Stadium">Parramatta Stadium</a>. In Round 4 against the <a href="Penrith%20Panthers">Penrith Panthers</a>, Ma’u scored his first NRL career try in the 32-16 win at Parramatta Stadium. On 5 June 2014, Ma’u extended his contract with the Eels for a further three years to the end of the 2017 season. In Round 14 against the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a> at <a href="ANZ%20Stadium">ANZ Stadium</a>, Ma’u debut year in the NRL was over after suffering a fractured forearm in the Eels 22-12 win. Ma’u finished off his debut year in the NRL with him playing in 13 matches and scoring a try for the Eels in the 2014 NRL season.
2015.
On 31 January and 1 February, Ma'u played for the Eels in the <a href="2015%20NRL%20Auckland%20Nines">2015 NRL Auckland Nines</a>. On 2 May, Ma'u represented <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> in their <a href="Pacific%20Rugby%20League%20International%23Polynesian%20Cup">2015 Polynesian Cup</a> test-match against Pacific rivals <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a>, playing at second-row in Tonga's 18-16 loss at <a href="Robina%20Stadium">Cbus Super Stadium</a>. He finished off the <a href="2015%20NRL%20season">2015 season</a> having played in 22 matches and scoring 5 tries for Eels. On 8 September, he was named in the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> train-on squad, however didn't make the final squad so played for Tonga in their <a href="2017%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28Asia-Pacific%20play-off%29">Asia-Pacific Qualifier</a> match against the <a href="Cook%20Islands%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Cook Islands</a> for the <a href="2017%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2017 Rugby League World Cup</a>, playing at second-row in Tonga's 28-8 win at <a href="Campbelltown%20Stadium">Campbelltown Stadium</a>.
2016.
On 1 February 2016, Ma'u was named in the Eels' <a href="2016%20NRL%20Auckland%20Nines">2016 NRL Auckland Nines</a> squad. On 6 May 2016, Ma'u made his debut for <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> in the <a href="2016%20Anzac%20Test">2016 Anzac Test</a>, starting at second-row in the 16-0 loss at <a href="Hunter%20Stadium">Hunter Stadium</a>. On 15 September 2016 at the Eels presentation night, Ma’u was awarded with the Ken Thornett Medal as being the club's Players’ Player of the year. Ma’u finished the <a href="2016%20NRL%20season">2016 NRL season</a> with him playing in 22 matches and scoring 2 tries for the Eels. On 25 September 2016, Ma’u was rewarded for his solid season with the club by getting his contract extended to the end of the 2019 season. On 4 October 2016, Ma’u was selected in the New Zealand Kiwis 24-man squad for the <a href="2016%20Rugby%20League%20Four%20Nations">2016 Four Nations</a>. Ma’u played in all 5 matches of the tournament including starting at second-row in the Kiwis 34-8 Four Nations Final loss against Australia at <a href="Anfield">Anfield</a>.
2017.
In the 2017 season, Ma'u played 24 games for Parramatta as they finished fourth on the table at the end of the season and qualified for the finals which was the club's first appearance since the 2009 season.
Ma'u elected to switch his national allegiance <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> in 2017. He was named in the <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> squad for the <a href="2017%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2017 Rugby League World Cup</a> and played in every match of their historic charge to the semi-finals. He scored a try in their victory over arch-rivals <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a>.
2018.
On 27 June 2018, Ma'u was ruled out for the rest of the season after suffering a fractured cheekbone in a middle of the season test match while playing for Tonga against Samoa. Even though Parramatta were running last at the time, Ma'u was cited as being one of the better players in the struggling side.
2019.
After missing the start of the season through injury, Ma'u made his return for Parramatta in Round 7 against Newcastle scoring a try in a 28-14 loss.
On 8 July 2019, it was announced that Ma'u had signed a 2-year deal with <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in England starting in the 2020 Super League season.
At the end of the 2019 regular season, Parramatta finished in 5th place on the table and qualified for the finals. In the elimination final against Brisbane, Ma'u kicked a goal in his last home game as Parramatta won the match 58-0 at the new <a href="Western%20Sydney%20Stadium">Western Sydney Stadium</a>. The victory was the biggest finals win in history, eclipsing Newtown's 55-7 win over St George in 1944. The match was also Parramatta's biggest win over Brisbane and Brisbane's worst ever loss since entering the competition in 1988.
Ma'u played his final game for Parramatta the following week as the club were defeated 32-0 by Melbourne in the elimination semi final at <a href="AAMI%20Park">AAMI Park</a>.
2020.
He played 11 games for <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the 2020 Super League season including the semi-final defeat against <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a>.
